page.title: 02Ecology of Hebden Royd
page.content: The higher parts of our area are moorland. Underneath them the stone is mainly millstone grit. Peat is very common. Some predatory animals live there like stoats, foxes and weasels. Moors are usually situated above the 400m counter. Rough pasture is found on the edge of the moors. It is land which the early eighteenth century farmers "brought in"from the moors by draining ploughing and seeding. Most of the rough pasture land is between 300m and 400m above sea level. Farmland is land which is used as silage, hayfields and pastureland. It is usually level.Most of our wildlife is found in the woodland zone the dominant trees of the district are silver birch oak hawthorn beech and sycamore. The towns stretch along the Calder Valley.
